content.description:
Follow the bolts. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.13a).
content.protection: 4 bolts (bolted anchor)Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: Low alcove with two right-facing corners. 35-40 feet right (east / southeast) of the obvious Stairway to Heaven crack/flake system.   The next bolted line to the right (about 20 feet) from Thunderstud.

content.description:
Follow the bolts. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.11a).  

  . (sometimes dryer than other routes on the Rear Wall).
content.protection:
3 bolts (but likely no top anchor bolts). 

  Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: In the right (east) half of the Rear Wall, 20 feet Right from the alcove and bolt line of War and Peace.

content.description: Climb the crack to the right of the Bitch is Back. Short climb but very fun.
content.location: Crack left of the Bitch is Back.

content.description:
Some balancing skill takes you to the third bolt crux, can be done statically but a tricky dyno gets the job done. The climbing eases after the crux but is still sustained. Coerce your partner to lead it first to brush off the spider webs.

 "The route Thunder Stud that was put up by Albert Pisaneschi who led it and bolted it. He is not on social media and asked me to have someone change this on the web. I have his phone number if you need to speak to him to verify this. He has quietly put up many routes without writing guides and other people have taken the credit." - nancy savickas
content.protection:
Bolts.

 "There is an anchor (as of April 2018) however it is on the top of the cliff nearly a foot from the lip. Make a nice long anchor to drape over the edge or top out and walk off because whomever bolted this anchor did not want you going home with a sheath still on your rope." - Nick Best
content.location: The next route to the right of Stairway to Heaven.  Follows a flake after the first clip until the crux.

climbs.name: Sad, Sloppy, Worthless, and Weak
climbs.fa: Bob D, G Peterson, A Pisaneschi

content.description:
Up the rounded right-facing corner, next by a vague left-facing corner, then right-ward to a ledge. Then up and left to finish 12-15 feet right (east) of the mature pine tree at edge of cliff. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10a). 

  Sometimes dryer than other routes on the Rear Wall.
content.protection:
4 bolts (likely no top anchor bolts). 

  Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: In the left / north half of the Rear Wall, at a rounded right-facing corner with a crack that slants right-ward. About ten or fifteen feet left of the obvious Stairway to Heaven crack/flake system.

content.description:
Up the crack and through the roof, up the left-facing corner. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10b).
content.protection:
No bolts. 

  Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: At a crack which goes up through low roof into a left-facing corner above - (which is to the right of a right-facing right-slanting corner that starts ten feet off the ground). About 22 feet Right (east) from the bolt line of the unnamed route.

content.description:
Climb up to the top as best you can. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10d).
content.protection: Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: Below right-facing right-slanting corner that starts 10 feet off the ground. About twelve feet Right (east) from the bolt line of the unnamed route.

climbs.name: Pine Line
climbs.fa: N. Morell, G. Peterson, R. Holzman

content.description: Sustained climbing with a dominant crux after the second clip.  The first bolt might seem a bit high off the ground but the climbing is easy.  The crux is is a touch painful, incorporating the left jug is true to the grade but going direct seems more natural.
content.location: The first route on the left side of the corridor

content.description: Crux is low and with a big reach.

Find a way up. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10b).
content.protection:
No bolts. 

  Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: To the right of the Ryan's Crack.   ? (perhaps the "knotty pine" died and disappeared) ?

climbs.name: K.B.
climbs.fa: Bob D., G. Peterson, A. Pisaneschi

content.description: Good climbing with a dominant crux after the second bolt, may seem a little harder until you figure out the sequence.  The first ascentionists named it after Kevin Bein, one of the climbing greats who died on the Matterhorn.
content.location: Same start as Pine Line, cut right after the first bolt, rap off the tree overhanging the route.

content.description: Up that cliff section with few features.
content.protection: Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: Section of the cliff with few features on the right side of War and Peace.

content.description:
Up by the indented overhanging nose to obvious ledge. Next angle six feet Right-ward, then up to finish just left of obvious notch. 

  . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10a/b). 

  Upper sections sometimes dryer than other routes on the Rear Wall.
content.protection:
3 bolts (but likely no top anchor bolts). 

  Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff, using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.
content.location: In the left / north half of the Rear Wall, at an indented overhanging nose. Just left of the obvious Stairway to Heaven crack/flake system.   . (This bolted line is "squeezed" closely between the adjacent routes).

content.description:
The east wall of the interior corridor of the Library -- not on the detached block at all. 

  When approaching from Paradise, the main thing you see is the large detached block. Then when you get there you discover a corridor behind the block, between the main block and a "normal" non-detached cliff face. The corridor and the two main faces of the block all run roughly SSW to NNE. The widest and easiest entrance to the corridor is on its NNE end.
